text: APPLICATION:
label: BODY

text: Application for Status as a Temporary Resident pursuant to Section 245A of the
label: BODY

text: Immigration and Nationality Act, as amended, 8 U.S.C. 5 1255a
label: BODY

text: ON BEHALF OF APPLICANT:
label: BODY

text: INSTRUCTIONS:
label: BODY

text: This is the decision of the Administrative Appeals Office in your case. If your appeal was dismissed or
label: BODY

text: rejected, all documents have been returned to the National Benefits Center. You no longer have a case
label: BODY

text: pending before this office, and you are not entitled to file a motion to reopen or reconsider your case. If your
label: BODY

text: appeal was sustained or remanded for further action, you will be contacted.
label: BODY

text: Perry Rhew
label: BODY

text: Chief, Administrative Appeals Office
label: BODY

text: Page 2
label: BODY

text: DISCUSSION: The application for temporary resident status pursuant to the terms of the settlement
label: BODY

text: agreements reached in Catholic Social Services, Inc., et al., v. Ridge, et al., CIV. NO. S-86-1343-
label: BODY

text: LKK (E.D. Cal) January 23, 2004, and Felicity Mary Newman, et al., v. United States Immigration
label: BODY

text: and Citizenship Services, et al., CIV. NO. 87-4757-WDK (C.D. Cal) February 17, 2004
label: BODY

text: (CSS/Newman Settlement Agreements), was denied by the Director, Houston. The decision is now
label: BODY

text: before the Administrative Appeals Office (AAO) on appeal. The appeal will be dismissed.
label: BODY

text: The applicant submitted a Form 1-687, ,4pplication for Status as a Temporary Resident under Section
label: BODY

text: 245A of the Immigration and Nationality Act (Act), and a Form 1-687 Supplement, CSS/Newman Class
label: BODY

text: Membership Worksheet. The director denied the application, finding that the applicant had not
label: BODY

text: established by a preponderance of the evidence that he had continuously resided in the United States
label: BODY

text: in an unlawful status for the duration of the requisite period.
label: BODY

text: On appeal, the applicant, through counsel, asserts that he has established his unlawful residence for
label: BODY

text: the requisite time period.
label: BODY

text: An applicant for temporary resident status must establish entry into the United States before January 1,
label: BODY

text: 1982, and continuous residence in the United States in an unlawfkl status since such date and through
label: BODY

text: the date the application is filed. Section 245A(a)(2) of the Act, 8 U.S.C. 5 1255a(a)(2). The applicant
label: BODY

text: must also establish that he or she has been continuously physically present in the United States since
label: BODY

text: November 6, 1986. Section 245A(a)(3) of the Act, 8 U.S.C. 5 1255a(a)(3). The regulations clarify
label: BODY

text: that the applicant must have been physically present in the United States from November 6, 1986
label: BODY

text: until the date of filing the application. 8 C.F.R. 9 245a.2(b).
label: BODY

text: For purposes of establishing residence and physical presence under the CSS/Newman Settlement
label: BODY

text: Agreements, the term "until the date of filing" in 8 C.F.R. 5 245a.2(b) means until the date the
label: BODY

text: applicant attempted to file a completed Form 1-687 application and fee or was caused not to timely
label: BODY

text: file during the original legalization application period of May 5, 1987 to May 4, 1988. CSS
label: BODY

text: Settlement Agreement paragraph 11 at page 6; Newman Settlement Agreement paragraph 11 at page
label: BODY

text: The applicant has the burden of proving by a preponderance of the evidence that he or she has resided in
label: BODY

text: the United States for the requisite periods, is admissible to the United States under the provisions of
label: BODY

text: section 245A of the Act, and is otherwise eligible for adjustment of status. The inference to be drawn
label: BODY

text: from the documentation provided shall depend on the extent of the documentation, its credibility and
label: BODY

text: amenability to verification. 8 C.F.R. 5 245a.2(d)(5).
label: BODY

text: Although the regulation at 8 C.F.R. 5 245a.2(d)(3) provides an illustrative list of contemporaneous
label: BODY

text: documents that an applicant may submit in support of his or her claim of continuous residence in the
label: BODY

text: United States in an unlawful status since prior to January 1, 1982, the submission of any other
label: BODY

text: relevant document is permitted pursuant to 8 C.F.R. $245a.2(d)(3)(vi)(L). To meet his or her
label: BODY

text: burden of proof, an applicant must provide evidence of eligibility apart from the applicant's own
label: BODY

text: testimony, and the sufficiency of all evidence produced by the applicant will be judged according to
label: BODY

text: its probative value and credibility. 8 C.F.R. 5 245a.2(d)(6).
label: BODY

text: The "preponderance of the evidence" standard requires that the evidence demonstrate that the
label: BODY

text: applicant's claim is "probably true," where the determination of "truth" is made based on the factual
label: BODY

text: circumstances of each individual case. Matter of E-M-, 20 I&N Dec. 77, 79-80 (Comm. 1989). In
label: BODY

text: evaluating the evidence, Matter of E--44- also stated that "[tlruth is to be determined not by the
label: BODY

text: quantity of evidence alone but by its quality." Id. Thus, in adjudicating the application pursuant to
label: BODY

text: the preponderance of the evidence standard, the director must examine each piece of evidence for
label: BODY

text: relevance, probative value, and credibility, both individually and within the context of the totality of
label: BODY

text: the evidence, to determine whether the fact to be proven is probably true. See 8 C.F.R. 5
label: BODY

text: 245a.2(d)(6). The weight to be given any affidavit depends on the totality of the circumstances, and
label: BODY

text: a number of factors must be considered. More weight will be given to an affidavit in which the
label: BODY

text: affiant indicates personal knowledge of the applicant's whereabouts during the time period in
label: BODY

text: question rather than a fill-in-the-blank affidavit that provides generic information. The regulations
label: BODY

text: provide specific guidance on the sufficiency of documentation when proving residence through
label: BODY

text: evidence of past employment or attestations by churches or other organizations. 8 C.F.R. $5
label: BODY

text: Even if the director has some doubt as to the truth, if the applicant submits relevant, probative, and
label: BODY

text: credible evidence that leads the director to believe that the claim is "probably true" or "more likely
label: BODY

text: than not," the applicant or petitioner has satisfied the standard of proof. See US. v. Cardozo-
label: BODY

text: Fonseca, 480 U.S. 421 (1987) (defining "more likely than not" as a greater than 50 percent
label: BODY

text: probability of something occurring). If the director can articulate a material doubt, it is appropriate
label: BODY

text: for the director to either request additional evidence or, if that doubt leads the director to believe that
label: BODY

text: the claim is probably not true, deny the application or petition.
label: BODY

text: The issue in this proceeding is whether the applicant (1) entered the United States before January 1,
label: BODY

text: 1982 and (2) has continuously resided in the United States in an unlawfbl status for the requisite period
label: BODY

text: of time. The documentation that the applicant submits in support of his claim to have arrived in the
label: BODY

text: United States before January 1982 and lived in continuous unlawful status during the requisite
label: BODY

text: period consists of affidavits. Some of the evidence submitted indicates that the applicant resided in
label: BODY

text: the United States after May 4, 1988; however, because evidence of residence after May 4, 1988 is
label: BODY

text: not probative of residence during the requisite time period, it shall not be discussed.
label: BODY

text: statements that the affiants have known the applicant for years and that attest to the applicant being
label: BODY

text: physically present in the United States during all or part of the required period. These affiants fail,
label: BODY

text: however, to establish the applicant's continuous unlawful residence in the United States for the
label: BODY

text: duration of the requisite period. As stated previously, the evidence must be evaluated not by the
label: BODY

text: quantity of evidence alone but by its quality; an applicant must provide evidence of eligibility apart
label: BODY

text: from his or her own testimony; and the sufficiency of all evidence produced by the applicant will be
label: BODY

text: judged according to its probative value and credibility.
label: BODY

text: None of the witness statements provide concrete information, specific to the applicant and generated
label: BODY

text: by the asserted associations with him, which would reflect and corroborate the extent of those
label: BODY

text: associations and demonstrate that they were a sufficient basis for reliable knowledge about the
label: BODY

text: applicant's residence during the time addressed in the affidavits. To be considered probative and
label: BODY

text: credible, witness affidavits must do more than simply state that an affiant knows an applicant and
label: BODY

text: that the applicant has lived in the United States for a specific time period. Their content must
label: BODY

text: include sufficient detail from a claimed relationship to indicate that the relationship probably did
label: BODY

text: exist and that the witness does, by virtue of that relationship, have knowledge of the facts alleged.
label: BODY

text: Upon review, the AAO finds that, individually and together, the witness statements do not indicate
label: BODY

text: that their assertions are probably true. Therefore, they have little probative value.
label: BODY

text: The remaining evidence in the record is comprised of the applicant's statements and application
label: BODY

text: forms, in which he claims to have entered the United States in 1979. The AAO notes that the record
label: BODY

text: of proceeding contains inconsistent information regarding when the applicant first arrived in the
label: BODY

text: United States. In her February 27, 2008 notice of intent to deny (NOID), the director stated that
label: BODY

text: during his June 1, 2006 interview, the applicant stated that he first entered the United States in April
label: BODY

text: 1982, and in 1984 he was sent to Mexico by an immigration officer, and re-entered the United States
label: BODY

text: in 1986. It is incumbent upon the applicant to resolve any inconsistencies in the record by
label: BODY

text: independent objective evidence. Any attempt to explain or reconcile such inconsistencies will not
label: BODY

text: suffice unless the petitioner submits competent objective evidence pointing to where the truth lies.
label: BODY

text: Doubt cast on any aspect of the applicant's proof may lead to a reevaluation of the reliability and
label: BODY

text: sufficiency of the remaining evidence offered in support of the application. See Matter of Ho, 19
label: BODY

text: I&N Dec. 582, 591-92 (BIA 1988). The applicant has not submitted any additional evidence in
label: BODY

text: support of his claim that he was physically present or had continuous residence in the United States
label: BODY

text: during the entire requisite period or that he entered the United States in 1979.
label: BODY

text: On appeal, counsel asserts that the director did not consider the applicant's response to the director's
label: BODY

text: NOID. The applicant's response to the director's NOID consists of assertion by the applicant,
label: BODY

text: through counseli that he entered the United States prior to January 1, 1982 and an affidavit from his
label: BODY

text: brother
label: BODY

text: stating that the applicant lived with him in Texas from 1979 to 1986. The
label: BODY

text: applicant's response to the director's NOID does address the director's concerns regarding his
label: BODY

text: inconsistent statements during the interview. As stated previously, doubt cast on any aspect of the
label: BODY

text: applicant's proof may lead to a reevaluation of the reliability and sufficiency of the remaining
label: BODY

text: evidence offered in support of the application. See Matter of Ho, supra. Upon a de novo review of
label: BODY

text: all of the evidence in the record, the AAO agrees with the director that the evidence submitted by the
label: BODY

text: applicant has not established that he is eligible for the benefit sought.
label: BODY

text: Therefore, based upon the foregoing, the applicant has failed to establish by a preponderance of the
label: BODY

text: evidence that he entered the United States before January 1, 1982 and continuously resided in an
label: BODY

text: unlawful status in the United States for the requisite period as required under both 8 C.F.R.
label: BODY

text: 5 245a.2(d)(5) and Matter of E- M--, supra. The applicant is, therefore, ineligible for temporary
label: BODY

text: resident status under section 245A of the Act on this basis.
label: BODY

text: ORDER:
label: HH1

text: The appeal is dismissed. This decision constitutes a final notice of ineligibility.
label: BODY
